definition: Liu Bang (256 or 247-195 BC), bandit leader who became first Han emperor Han Gaozu 漢高祖|汉高祖 (reigned 202-195 BC)
(classical) a type of battle-ax/to kill/to slaughter
surname Liu
country/nation/state

sentences.english: After my wound is healed, I will go to Liu Bang .
sentences.chinese: 等我的傷口治好了，我將會去劉邦那。

sentences.english: This night, they ran along with the path in ZeZhong.
sentences.chinese: 當晚，劉邦一行人在澤中小道逃跑。

sentences.english: Liu Bang established Western Han Dynasty, and he consolidated the centralized feudal state.
sentences.chinese: 劉邦建立了西漢，鞏固了中央集權的封建國家。

sentences.english: Liu Bang established the powerful Han Dynasty in 206 B. C.
sentences.chinese: 公元前206年，劉邦建立了強大的漢王朝。

sentences.english: Third, Liu Bang are not satisfied with the feudality from Shiang Yu.
sentences.chinese: 三是劉邦對項羽分封的不滿。

sentences.english: How did Liu Bang, who was described by Tai Shigong , embody the life wisdom of the ancients?
sentences.chinese: 太史公筆下的劉邦，又是如何表現古人的人生聰明？

sentences.english: Liu bang from _ the uprising to WangMang reigned han dynasty, across two hundred DuoNian of time and space.
sentences.chinese: 從_劉邦起義反秦到王莽篡漢，橫跨二百多年時空。

sentences.english: Liu Bang also could enjoy pop music in palace chambers.
sentences.chinese: 連劉邦也只能在宮闈中享受一番家鄉情調。

definition: Xiang Yu the Conqueror (232-202 BC), warlord defeated by first Han emperor
Han Xin (-196 BC), famous general of first Han emperor Liu Bang 劉邦|刘邦[Liu2 Bang1]
Liu Bei (161-223), warlord at the end of the Han dynasty and founder of the Han kingdom of Shu 蜀漢|蜀汉 (c. 200-263), later the Shu Han dynasty

Di Renjie (607-700), Tang dynasty politician, prime minister under Wu Zetian, subsequently hero of legends/master sleuth Judge Dee, aka Chinese Sherlock Holmes, in novel Three murder cases solved by Judge Dee 狄公案[Di2 gong1 an4] translated by Dutch sinologist R.H. van Gulik 高羅珮|高罗佩[Gao1 Luo2 pei4]
Wu Zetian (624-705), Tang empress, reigned 690-705
the state of Chu, one of the most important of the small states contending for power in China between 770 and 223 BC, located around present-day Hubei
Emperor Wu of the Han dynasty (141-87 BC)
monarch
stratagem/strategy/resourcefulness
Han Dynasty (206 BC-220 AD)
Lü Bu (-198), general and warlord
skilled manipulator/tactician/strategist/advisor/counsellor
Wei State (407-225 BC), one of the Seven Hero States of the Warring States 戰國七雄|战国七雄/Wei State or Cao Wei 曹魏 (220-265), the most powerful of the Three Kingdoms
commander-in-chief, the equivalent of king in Chinese chess
Sun Quan (reigned 222-252), southern warlord and king of state of Wu 吳|吴 in the Three Kingdoms period
the state of Qin, one of the seven states of the Warring States Period (475-220 BC)
